title: The Five Levers to Affect Longevity
content: In this episode, Peter explains the various levers one can pull to affect longevity with a specific focus on the strategies and tactics one can implement that do not require the help of a physician.

title: Nutritional Biochemistry
content: Peter discusses the framework, 3 nutritional interventions, and how to approach your goals, and what you should be tracking.

title: Exercise for Brain Health
content: Peter talks about the 4 components of exercise, stability, strength, zone 2 and zone 5 training, and what he is optimizing for with his exercise.

title: DNS and Neuromuscular Development Stages
content: Peter explains more about DNS and why we need to be careful with rushing kids through neuromuscular development stages.

title: Sleep Quantity and Quality
content: Peter discusses how to improve sleep quantity and quality.

title: Exercise Physiology
content: The podcast is going to focus today on things that one can do that specifically does not require the help of a physician.

title: Nutritional Biochemistry
content: Nutrition…might be the most complicated because I think it has the most variable response for a given individual to a given stimulus. The overarching principle of nutritional biochemistry is you have to be malleable, you have to be empirical, and you have to assume that if it doesn’t work and you’ve tried it correctly, that that’s okay. And that there’s another approach.

title: Framework for Nutrition
content: Framework for nutrition: The 3 nutritional interventions/restrictions: -1) Dietary restriction, -2) Time restriction, -3) Caloric restriction. These three approaches can be done separately or can be combined.

title: Peter's Current Approach
content: Peter’s current approach: Dietary restriction alone. He is pretty much eating however much he wants, whenever he wants, but he is being “manically strict” on what he’s eating. He’s completely restricting carbohydrates outside of vegetables – no starch whatsoever. This dietary approach has worked really well for Peter when he wants to lose a few pounds.

title: How to Approach Your Nutritional Goals
content: How to approach your nutritional goals.

title: Different approaches to weight loss
content: Peter acknowledges that the same approach to weight loss won't work for everyone. Some people lose weight when condensing their eating window, while others need dietary restriction. He advises people to know what they're trying to address, figure out how to measure it, stick with a plan long enough to assess it, and be ready to abandon it if it doesn't work.

title: The importance of blood glucose
content: Peter believes that the continuous glucose monitor (CGM) is the single most important wearable at the moment. He follows a very strict modicum of dietary restriction in the form of carbohydrate restriction, which results in very flat and low blood glucose levels with low variability. He thinks that the CGM will soon be available to the public and will be part of the solution for anyone who's in the do-it-yourself category.

title: Subcutaneous fat vs. visceral fat
content: Peter explains that much of the weight loss may come from subcutaneous fat, which doesn't play an enormous role in our health. It's the visceral fat that is by far the bigger predator, but it's very difficult to ascertain visceral fat loss.

title: Ordering blood tests without a physician
content: Peter thinks that patients should be able to order their blood tests without a physician, but he also believes that there is a benefit to having a physician who can help you understand and interpret the results, especially in the event that something is not optimal.

title: Pay attention to how you feel
content: Peter emphasizes that how you feel can't be overstated. If a nutritional intervention results in more and stable energy, less GI distress, better sleep, less cravings, and more satiation with meals, these would be signs that the changes you've made have been in the right direction even if they aren't accompanied by some of the more obvious things that we look at, such as a lower number on the scale.

title: Transitioning to ketosis
content: When Peter transitioned to a ketogenic diet in 2011, he ignored the advice to back off the intensity and volume of his workouts. He eventually learned that his muscles had to learn to burn fatty acids and ketones at a much broader range of ATP requirement. It took him almost 1.5 years to have an anaerobic click above FTP up until VO2 max.

title: Exercise for brain health
content: Exercise and nutrition are really potent physiologic tools. In fact, I don’t know how you’d quantify it, dose for dose, but certainly exercise [and sleep] might be the most important tool we have with respect to brain health. Exercise and sleep are the two most potent nootropics we have available, says Peter. Until you have your sleep fully optimized and you’re exercising every day and producing bucket loads of BDNF, lay off the nootropics and get those two things tuned up. You’re going to do more for your cognitive performance and for your long-term brain health by having these two pillars optimized than any stack of nootropics that has ever been concocted.

title: The 4 components of exercise
content: The 4 components of exercise: 1 | Stability (the foundation) 2 | Strength 3 | Zone 2 aerobic training 4 | Zone 5 (high intensity, e.g., HIIT)

title: Exercise component—Stability
content: [Stability] is the cornerstone upon which your strength is delivered, your aerobic performance is delivered and your anaerobic performance is delivered. And it’s the way that you do so safely. Stability is a way that we transmit force from the body to the outside world… in the safest manner possible… across the muscles which are designed to carry that load… as opposed to seeing the dissipation of force across joints that are not fit to do so. Humans are born with this ability. But we lose it over time because of our lack of activity and our abundance of sitting. But it’s possible to reacquire this ability through deliberate practice of these movements. Stability is probably what I think of as the foundation upon which everything should be done vis-a-vis exercise.

title: Exercise component—Strength
content: Strength means basically utilizing the muscle to generate force. So strength training with weights (or body weight) is a very important part of strength. This is I think the most intimidating of the four types of exercise especially for people who have not done it before.

title: Importance of Muscle Mass and Bone Density
content: Peter emphasizes the importance of muscle mass and bone density for longevity. He believes that prioritizing muscle mass is crucial for longevity and that lifting weights can improve bone density.

title: Optimizing for Longevity
content: Peter optimizes his exercise routine for longevity rather than performance. He trains for the Centenarian Decathlon, which means training in Zone 2 and Zone 5. He believes that training in these zones will help him be a kickass 90-year-old.

title: Zone 2 Training
content: Zone 2 is the highest level of exertion that is effectively pure mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation before you start to net accumulate lactate. Peter does Zone 2 training about four times per week using a lactate meter to make sure he is right on that limit of not going too far. He usually does it on a stationary bike or a treadmill.

title: Zone 5 Training
content: Zone 5 is high-intensity training, and Peter believes neglecting it completely will come at a cost. He describes this zone as a small part of life and recommends doing it twice a week. HIIT is more efficient than aerobic exercise on a minute per minute or unit time basis, but Peter does not view it as an either/or situation.

title: Peter's Typical Week of Exercise
content: Peter's typical week of exercise includes 3-5 bouts of strength training, 4 bouts of Zone 2, 2 bouts of Zone 5, and stability training sprinkled into pretty much every day. He recommends measuring blood lactate concentrations to know if you are actually in Zone 2.

title: Lactate Threshold
content: Being at ~2.0 mM (or probably just below it at 1.8, 1.9) is the gold standard because that is the definition. That definition is the highest generation of ATP that is coming through the mitochondria such that you are not net accumulating lactate. Lactate meter that Peter recommends: Lactate Plus Meter by Nova. Heads up, it’s not cheap for the device or the strips. TIP: You need to use very clean soapy water to wash your hands before doing a blood test. Alcohol is not sufficient because it does not remove lactate.

title: Rate of Perceived Exertion
content: RPE of 3 to 4 on a scale of 1-10 is generally where you should be. However, Peter finds the idea of rating your exertion on a scale of 1-10 rather difficult. Instead, Peter prefers to gauge it by your ability to hold a conversation: Once you’re at the point when it becomes annoying to talk during that form of exercise, you’ve hit that threshold. (i.e., you can talk, but you don’t want to)

title: Maximum Heart Rate
content: 69% to 83% of your heart rate max should be zone 2. Peter points out however that it varies quite widely from person to person. You really need to know your true max HR (you can’t just use the 220-age formula). Once you know your true max HR, Peter suggests starting out at 75% of max HR. *Peter recommends that most people use one of the 3 options above for assessing their zone 2, however, there are a couple more ways to do it. Such as…

title: Lactate Threshold Heart Rate
content: 85% to 89% on a run (per Joe Friel). 81% to 89% on a bike. Oftentimes, onset of blood lactate accumulation (OBLA) is confused with the lactate threshold (read the difference here)

title: Functional Threshold Power (FTP)
content: FTP is the highest level of power you can hold for an hour. 56% to 75% of your FTP is zone 2. Note about determining your FTP: Rather than testing for a full 60 minutes, you can determine your FTP by doing 20 minutes of max effort and then take 90% of that max output as your FTP

title: DNS and Neuromuscular Development
content: Bob makes the analogy that zone two training is like you’re improving the stability of your mitochondria. You might even be thinking of free radical production from “leakage” as your mitochondria become more efficient organelles in the context of training. And with Olympic lifting, which may seem like all about performance, a good coach should watching closely and correcting any efficient movement or “leakage”. So in a way like that speaks to DNS being the foundation for all forms of exercise. It originated from at Prague school as a tool upon which one could study the developmental delay in children with cerebral palsy. And it was through that that they realized that kids with CP had missed certain developmental milestones. The initial thrust of DNS was how can we go back and teach these kids early enough in life once they’re diagnosed to learn these movement patterns that they would otherwise miss and to save them some of the challenges later on. Be care about rushing kids through natural stages of neuromuscular development: It’s common for kids to have hip dysplasia being born breached and to then be put in a hip harness for 6+ months. This is a really a horrible thing for a kid to be in because it really limits movement during a very critical period of development. Be careful with bumbo seats that put them up in a seated position prematurely before they have developed the truncal strength to support themselves or the stability. You’re rushing through a stage and they tend to then not develop the right connections across their torso. Same goes with those bouncer walker things. Or even putting shoes on kids too early. “There’s a whole bunch of things that we do as parents obviously with the best of intentions that actually kind of work against a child’s correct neuromuscular development.”

title: Improving your sleep
content: The #1 tip from Peter: Consistently getting enough time in bed. The goal should be to spend enough time in bed to give yourself an opportunity to sleep ~8 hours. Secondly, it’s ideal to get in bed and get out of bed at the same time every day. The more consistent your wake up time can be, the better you are because circadian rhythm is not exactly 24 hours and so you like having that morning reset every day. Keep that wake up time as consistent as possible even on the weekends.

title: Peter’s routine
content: He gets in bed before 9pm because his son wakes up at 5am. In an ideal world, his nighttime routine begins at least an hour before bed. Preferably, he doesn’t use electronics at night at all, but if he needs to he makes sure to wear blue light blockers (he uses Felix Gray).

title: Sleep trackers
content: Peter uses the Oura ring (full disclosure he’s an investor and advisor to Oura). Other trackers include Fitbit and Apple Watch.

title: Ways to improve your deep sleep
content: Blue light blocking glasses if you are going to look at electronics at night. A supplement called a magnesium L-threonate. Keeping the bed cool.

title: Other measure you can take to improve sleep
content: Don’t drink alcohol too close to bed (it’s harmful to sleep quality). Food intake too close to bed also has a negative impact (try to cut off food 3-4 hours before bed). Keep the room as dark as possible. Keep the room temperature cold. Going to bed earlier (try setting a “get in bed” alarm on your phone).

title: 3 sleep surveys you can take to assess your sleep proficiency
content: The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). Epworth Sleepiness Scale. Stop-Bang Questionnaire for assessing risk of sleep apnea.

title: Peter’s advice on sleep
content: For many people just getting this sleep hygiene dialed in with respect to electronics, blue light, temperature, a couple of supplements, timing of food, limiting alcohol, the discipline around the time in bed, darkness in the room, et cetera. I’m constantly amazed, Bob, at how many people want a single pill to solve this problem when in reality you have to take a broader approach to this and you’ll get much better results.
